title: I love immobile champs. The last years have been the worst.
body: Mobility creep only grows year after year... Why would I pick brand instead of lb? She can burst easily, is much better at laning phase, much safer and can escape easily from a bad situation.

replies.body:
Brand has much higher team fight potential damage and is better at taking objectives.  I'm curious as to why the first of those points isn't particularly poignant.  You have any thoughts on that matter?

Mind you, I'm not disagreeing.  I played Brand vs. Kassadin the other day, and felt the same way.  Kassadin's lane felt stronger, his priority-target burst felt more accessible, and I knew that he could push deeper and harder because he had good escape potential.  Likewise, I just got finished watching Faker's LeBlanc vs. a Heimerdinger in solo queue.  The Heimer actually outplayed LeBlanc quite a few times and yet, even as Heimer's team went on to win, I kind of felt bad for the little guy because he did get zoned some in lane, and when he capitalized it seemed more like LB's mistake than his stellar play.  

Generally speaking, Heimerdinger and Brand are better teamfighters than LeBlanc/Kass.  Over the years, they've almost always been stronger statistically speaking (they win more games).  Is doing AoE damage in team fights that lackluster?  Or is it more that the super mobile guys feel like champion's of their own fate, even if they're less successful?

You're right, Brand does have more team fight potential than Kassadin.

And that's why he's also a better team fighter than Lissandra. No wait, that's the opposite of the truth.

And that's why he's a better team fighter than Orianna. No wait, that's the opposite of the truth.

And that's why he's a better team fighter than Azir. No wait, that's the opposite of the truth.

Your entire post is "hey guys, assassin style mages team fight worse than AoE mages!" Well no shit. How about comparing team fight mages to team fight mages? You typed up three paragraphs that don't mean a thing. 

I was expecting the typical Riot bullshit on how they're going to work on mobility creep but this man... dude it's embarrassing for all of us when you try to make an obviously faulty argument. Why not say something like "you know what, mobility creep IS a problem!" Then we can all pretend your'e doing something about it for the next year until you release a champion with a gap closer on every auto attack. 

*(You have no idea how much I am struggling to force myself not to make a joke about analyzing the difference between AoE mages and assassin mages.) *
You're getting dramatic because I compared Brand and LeBlanc when the OP specifically asked that question?
Are you aware that you are replying to Hashinshin? He has a reputation for being dramatic (though I do like that he is passionate for the game.)
At least he didn't compare Brand to Zed... just saying. But, if any champion needs some compensation for mid lane, it would be {{champion:34}}.
I think the intent is why pick a stationary mage like Brand when you can pick a mobile one like LeBlanc? She wasn't the best comparison.

Except both of their damage is too inconsistent to justify the lack of mobility.

You are threatened by ganks, mobile characters are not. They can wipe one person off the face of the planet, wait 7 seconds an drop another to half. Not to mention both have better CC in a consistency fashion. Leblanc has a slow, bind that relies on nothing else but hitting it. 

Brand needs a marked target for his stun, and no way to make the shot easier. The stun is nothing spectacular either compared to other stuns in the game, nor is the damage. Compare it to Ahri's charm for example.

Heimer's has a giant tell and is much harder to hit in the sense that unlike a normal skill shot, it doesn't hit them if they dash towards it or run away. You have to predict for the exact place they would be at. 

Throw on that if they run away you are just boned and can't follow where as if you get engaged on you are just screwed unless you can 100-0 all of them.

The only character (imo) who has the burst, damage and lane control that is immobile and feels good to play (again, imo) is Ori cause she has a ton of utility on top of mass burst potential only reliant on her ball. but her ult has so much damage and CC that is immidiate, unlike Brand, Heimer, Victor(Victor does and doesn't, His CC is better then most imo but still not worth playing him over other options, and at least he has a movement speed increase and a good slow stun). Cass got number buffed until she was good even though I don't know anyone who "enjoys" playing her more then she is "strong now"(This is friends, not random people on the forum. Since its a better stat since smurf accounts and so forth). 

Veigar is getting changed in ways I dislike personally. Making him dramatically harder to play with less trade off. Which goes back to why Leblanc and Kass are just better, is because they can pick a target, and that target is probably screwed if you can't rip them off instantly. Same for Zed really. But Veigar no longer has the ability to pick a target and they are dead. No instant stun to give his dark matter time to land. No targeted q  so ignore the front line to pick a high priority target. No DFG ult combo. And anyone who can stack better with the new q(being a skill shot it will inherently be harder to stack, anyone who says other is assuming theoretically perfection that should be possible against any player of equal skill and since any good player should punish you for stacking it) probably had to put dozens of hours into play. And all for what? The double hit q, better mana costs(which were ruined by the mana changes anyway and is more ofa  fix for that) late game cooldown reduction(cause the game was hard cause of his late, not his early. So we made his early game worse) , and a debuff on his ult.

Veigar might be good. I suppose with his skill ceiling higher there is the potential for him to do better. But honestly? Where is the fun in picking him? Again, I haven't played him. But I'm the type of person who ran the numbers on elise and knew she was good top when she was released. Who knew the Cass rework was going to feel utterly awful with the numbers on that and the mechanic changes. I like running numbers and running scenarios. 

And in all scenarios where counter play is added to characters with no mobility, characters with mobility become more unenjoyable to play against. 

I still come to these forums hoping to see changes coming that will make my favorite characters(zero mobility characters, including supports, and tanks) more fun to play, or more viable or give mobility characters weakness that matters. And Kass getting his ult changed is a start, but after 3 years its hard for me to care with just that. 

Also Veigar getting played in the LCS after all this discussion on him felt timed so stupidly perfect. 

Also to add on the fact Kass and LB win statistically less over the years, wasn't that due to Kass and LB both being so bad for a year and a half nobody touched them? Also heimer didn't have that high of a win percentage before his rework did he? Brand maybe, I don't know, but he's always been unfun to me because his ult just kinda goes where it feels like and his stun doesn't feel good or his kit. If zero mobility mages as a rule could cast while movinng, I might be less of that opinion.

You mentioned a couple things that rang true to me. I don't like that it feels like the enemy has full control over my ultimate as Brand. The dagger digs in a bit deeper when you're against a super mobile person and in addition to outplaying you throughout lane, if they get hit by your ulti, they can bring it away from their team.  I don't even know how often it happens but I do know the thought of it bugs me! 

As for the winrates: forgive me for speaking very generally, but LB and Kass, even when they're staples of competitive play, don't necessarily win more than half of their games for we mortals in solo queue.  Heimerdinger, Brand, and AOE mages generally perform very well in solo queue. 

Ori feels good and I normally classify her on the immobile end of the spectrum because she doesn't have a dash but her W grants her surprising movement.  

Syndra follows the no cast time paradigm, and probably not coincidentally has been one of the immobile mages we've seen have a presence in competitive play.  Hard to say for sure how much of it was that bonus mobility and how much of it was a very dominant laning phase.
{{champion:63}} bring the bounces back up to 9 max, but with a base of 5 going up when hitting blazed targets? and/or make q go through targets? coughchoughignitehealshimandtocompensatenamicantcogh
You're onto something big.

not to press my luck, but are you talking about the ult, the q, and/or the ignite/nami interaction? i would take that ignite/nami interaction over an actual buff, just cuz it'd be funny as hell. forget balance, lets go for lulz!

The main thing that jumped out at me was the Ignite interaction.  I always think those ideas are clever. Problem is, when I think about it, my hardcore gamer wins out.  As fun/funny as it would be, I want my abilities to interact consistently and would get super frustrated if I wasted an Ignite on Brand.

Also, I've always been a fan of the 'more/more reliable bounces on Brand'. 

The Q idea at first I really didn't like.  Then I thought about how maybe it could pass through Abalze targets. And then I still wasn't the biggest fan but it was a fun thought exercise.  ;)

> As for the winrates: forgive me for speaking very generally, but LB and Kass, even when they're staples of competitive play, don't necessarily win more than half of their games for we mortals in solo queue. Heimerdinger, Brand, and AOE mages generally perform very well in solo queue.

And how much of that is because of the fact that Brand and co. have a very low pick rate, indicating their either picked in games where their lack of mobility isn't much of a weakness or because they're only picked by dedicated mains of a champion? In comparison, most mobile champions have higher pickrates, generally indicating the average person is either picking them in bad matchups, don't have the skills to make their mobility useful, or are just picking what they saw the pros do and have no idea how to play that champ.

I'm not saying you can't pick an immobile champion and do well, but it's telling that very few mobile champions are picked in the pro scene.

It is telling. And I don't know how much the popularity contributes to winning less. I do recall the time right before LeBlanc picked up steam in competitive, where she wasn't popular and even then had a low win rate.  

In terms of non-mobile mages that have somewhat comparable playrates and better winrates Annie and Xerath come to mind, but admittedly aren't the best examples.

LeBlanc can probably be explained by the fact that an average pug team doesn't have the coordination to use her greatest strength; LB can shut down a midlaner hard, and in teamfights, she can either kill someone outright or force them to back easily, giving her team and easy 4v5. That's easier to do with a pro team's coordination (faker just blew someone up, time to force baron) but good luck herding cats in solo queue, or in a less coordinated 5.

Xerath plays the mobility game by being so far back he might as well have a dash, and Annie does well for the same reason anyone with a good teamfight ult does well; a flash beardrop is a glowing neon sign for her allies to 'ATTACK NOW YOU IDIOTS.'

I think the biggest reason mobile champs tend to get a lot of complaints is twofold; first off, Riot is slowly phasing out targeted abilities, especially targeted CC, because it's low counterplay. That's kinda true, but it is basically the only counterplay available to mobile champions, since you can just point and click the LB and not try to play the game of 'is she going to dash? is she going to go back to her original postion? is she going to use her ult to dash again?' This tends to get Riot accused of favoring mobility because LC$BIGPLAYS and all that.

The other major reason is the aforementioned 'playing LB's game'. Whenever I beat a highly mobile champion, I generally don't feel like I won it because of what I did, but of what they did. I don't feel like I can act, but can only react; when I get a kill on a Yasuo as Cass, I don't feel 'haha, I have outsmarted you!', I feel 'you screwed that up BADLY, dude'. It's their game to lose;  whether or not it's true or not, it feels that way.

Hmmm.  I think we should lay some groundwork first.  I suspect you understand this following concept but I feel compelled to say it regardless.  When I give my opinion, I'm giving my own personal one. Sometimes I'll chime in with what the Riot thinks at large but more often than not, what I say is what I personally feel. Sometimes I get the impression that players think everyone at Riot is aligned.  We have a healthy(?) amount of disagreement internally on a number of topics, including some of the ones you asked about.  As a QA guy for the Game Systems team, a large part of my job is to give feedback regarding potential changes.  One of my biggest takeaways from my time here is that the first idea is almost never right. It takes a lot of iterations to get something up to the quality we strive for.  

Sorry for the big preamble. Without further ado:

> "disruptions(knock up/backs, stuns, displacements) have become too common and thus hurts champions with channeling ultimates" 

Leaning more towards disagree. I liked the Galio change to not respect Tenacity with his ult, but generally feel like those champions can play around the interrupts.  I get to play with super talented Malzahar players, though (I don't know why, but internally we got a lot of Malz mains).

> Or if I said "Annie is too binary with her Flash+R combo"...agree or disagree? Especially when her R is undodgeable.

I agree that it's too binary, and I think our team has moved gradually in the right direction by making Tibbers more important outside the initial burst. Disagree that it's undodgeable.  But that's a personal pet battle of mine.  If you play footsies around the outside of her range and force her to Flash I think people can avoid it (although, as we saw this weekend, it ain't easy) by matching Flashes.

> Or "Brand has potential, but never fully reaches it" or "Brand could use something beyond just damage"?

Agree that he rarely reaches his potential.  I think he does add more than just damage: he has his stun and often itemizes towards Rylai's so he provides a ridic long slow.  Not saying we shouldn't push him even further in that direction but I don't know if he's as one dimensional as people generally think. 

> But lo-and-behold, it turns out this [Ahri] was one area we both agreed on

This is actually something that we wouldn't have been in agreement on. I liked the Charm pattern, because it is incredibly frustrating for me to see an Ahri kill someone without landing her skillshots, when she has mobility to put her at proper angles to land them!  Because of the latest changes, Ahri will probably fill her role better, and may be healthier long term. But if you told me the basics of the change being: giving her less damage but less reliance on Charm with more mobility as compensation, I would not have thought it was a good idea.  

> Now if only we both agree that [Cassio] is just messed up hardcore as well...

So there were undoubtedly some mistakes made, but when I see the end result I'm not upset about it.  On occasion now, I see Cassio showing up in the LCS, hypercarrying!  That was kind of the dream.  On the rare occasion I play her I enjoy it more because I feel like I don't get 'cheated' out of Twin Fang combinations.  Our developers are talented, and generally have good vision.  That doesn't mean we're going to get it right on the first or second attempt but we're going to keep trying and hopefully end up somewhere good.
Cass doesn't suffer from a gameplay problem as much as she does a theme/identity problem. The is the poison mage, not some ap minigun with a hint of poison.

Not that win rate is the only thing that matters, of course, but it's hard to say that these champs are objectively weak, or that mobility creep has pushed them out of viability (particularly Ashe, who's sitting at a 54% win rate, best among ADCs and 8th highest in the game).

I won't deny that some of these champs are less rewarding to play now, be it relative to previous seasons, or just relative to newer champions. I'm not sure what the answer to this is, but I'm curious to hear what people think.

I don't have a particular champion to give as an example, but I do have some thoughts on why people view immobility as frustrating and mobility as more satisfying.

One of the large pushes of the design team has been for counterplay. From our perspective (which is primarily influenced by champion reworks, patches, and releases), it seems like this has resulted in a large number of abilities becoming skillshots, having longer cast times, or having charges/delays before you can benefit from the full effect. In a vacuum, this is a pretty neat idea; it allows a person to perform a powerful action, but also gives the recipient of that action some limited choices to outplay their opponent.

The issue is that mobility gives a champion a significant edge over their immobile counterparts under this new paradigm. A mobile champion can reduce the counterplay their abilities have by repositioning themselves (e.g. Lee Sin ward hops so his Q is undodgable) and can also drastically increase the counterplay that is available to them against their opponents' abilities (e.g. PBE Veigar throws down his E, so Zed just shadows away during the delay). 

An immobile champion, on the other hand, does not have these tools. This often forces the immobile champions to play reactively, which is frustrating. Rather than having the ability or the tools to outplay their opponents, they instead rely on the mistakes of their opponents or help from their teammates. This type of counterplay feels extremely unsatisfying. Most players prefer not to subject themselves to this frustration, unless they have an emotional attachment to a particular immobile champion.

Frankly, I think that the counterplay paradigm needs to shift. To become more satisfying, immobile champions need tools to proactively outplay their opponents, especially if their opponent is highly mobile. This can be done a variety of ways (e.g. changing the way mobility functions and interacts with abilities on a very basic level or changing the cast times, delays, and animations of immobile champions), but, unless something changes, immobile champions will largely remain unsatisfying and frustrating to play for the general playerbase.

This was a great, well-written post. Going to edit down to the core thing that's resonating with me:

> A mobile champion can reduce the counterplay their abilities have by repositioning themselves and can also drastically increase the counterplay that is available to them against their opponents' abilities. An immobile champion, on the other hand, does not have these tools. This often forces the immobile champions to play reactively, which is frustrating. To become more satisfying, immobile champions need tools to proactively outplay their opponents, especially if their opponent is highly mobile.

Pretty sure I'm understanding correctly, but I want to be sure. Let's say I'm playing Lux against Zed. If I throw my Q first, he can dodge it w/ his mobility. So my proactive ability is pretty limited, and I'm forced to hold it for when he tries to engage on me, and only use it reactively. Ideally, you'd want Lux to still have some kind of proactive action she can take in lane, even when Zed's mobility skill is up.

Is that a the general idea? If so, a few followup questions for discussion purposes:
